options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture.
None
none
Two live virtual seminars every week on Monday and Thursday morning over Zoom.
problem sets

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Fundamentals of naval engineering. Fire hazards, ship design, power considerations. Very in depth and navy-relevant.
Fundamental concepts in physics and how they applied to ships and their systems.
Naval engineering
Learned about practical techniques and skills in naval engineering and theories in physics related to ship propulsion, naval architecture and ship materials.
I took this class to gain a better understanding of how a ship works and operates as well as understand the construction principles behind it in order to apply it to the work that I do.

I learned more about the engineering systems aboard ships and submarines. Examples include the basics of a nuclear reactor, a little nuclear physics, damage control, engineering department chain of command, parts of a ship, and basic physics/thermodynamics.
Learned about the engineering on a naval ship

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There is a LOT of material covered in this course. Paring down to the most important/interesting things might allow for more in-depth explanations rather than having to speed through everything.
The course was structured and organized well.  Pace of the material was also appropriate.  A better review of the lecture slides to remove errors could have been done.
It was just a lot of information that seemed to be irrelevant at the moment, but I know it can't be taught any other way due to regulations

It was nice that the fundamental ideas of engineering were clearly communicated and emphasized.  The psets were straightforward and were a good complement to the lectures.  Tests were difficult even though they were open note (probably because of the time crunch), but that just forced me to study before.

I liked the real-world focus of the course.  If I had one recommendation, it would be to include more examples of where engineering ideas are applied directly to the navy/real world.  Definitely keep the nuke presentations, and maybe more analysis of casualties?  That day we talked about the USS Cole and DC was a perfect example of tying the lectures to real world events.

Strengths: Extremely well-organized slides with good visuals that helped me understand the concepts. Instructor used personal testimony to help illustrate the relevance of the course to the fleet, which I extremely enjoyed. Instructor breaks down intimidating, complex topics in engineering and applied physics into understandable and enjoyable content for a non-STEM major. Small class size was nice for Q and As. Workload was extremely reasonable as well. Also, the class slack page was extremely great for collaboration. Organization of curriculum was excellent. Weaknesses: Few, if not any even during a difficult time of the pandemic.
The class lectures were always very clear. I do, however, wish that the lectures were recorded due to the occasional times that I missed something.
LT Ordway is a knowledgeable instructor and relayed the information well. He also provided PowerPoint slides of the lectures, which was useful.

Strengths: nice instructor, problem sets and exams weren't too bad
weaknesses: I didn't like the subject material, but have to take it due to ROTC requirements.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was fine as a live virtual lecture.
Given the circumstances, not much could have been done to improve the learning.  I cannot think of anything to improve the course in this way.

I wish we solved more problems before we were given psets because at the beginning it felt like we were learning completely different things in class compared to what was on the pset, or even if it was the same thing, I had a difficult time translating between theory and application
Virtual format was fine; felt that the 5-min breaks given were extremely helpful.

Considering the circumstances, the course was still very informative and I believe everything that was supposed to be covered in the course, did. 
LT Ordway kept us engaged and worked with us to make sure we gained the knowledge that was needed to not only pass this course but to apply it to real-life situations.
The live lectures were exactly what I was looking for in the pandemic, as they are much more interactive than recorded lectures and keeps one accountable. The open-book exams were also useful.
the lectures were a bit dull, especially so early in the morning

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it's interesting stuff! Especially if you're an engineering student and want to see things in the light of specific applications.
Yes, depending on their major.  It can provide interesting insight to physics and ship design for students not in the Navy.
Only if for ROTC
I would recommend this course for any student interested in the engineering principles of the Navy, which could be extended to any maritime field.
I would because it is necessary to know and understand when living on a ship.

Yes, but only if you want knowledge of the engineering physics and engineering organization/system on Navy ships and submarines. This course covers a lot of broad topics, but doesn't go too in-depth to any one. If you love thermodynamics and fluid mechanics and want to see how that applies to the pumps in Navy ships, take this course; but don't take it for in depth thermo or fluid mechanics knowledge.
only if they really wanted to learn about it, you don't get Yale College credit for it though.
